results.title: Julius Caesar (Heston/Gielgud)
results.creator_credit: Commonwealth United, Republic Pictures Corporation, Peter Snell and Stuart Burge
results.brief_description: Shakespeare’s epic tragedy is brought to the screen in this British production with an all-star cast. Charlton Heston stars as Mark Antony, John Gielgud as Caeser and Jason Robards as Brutus. Opposed to the growing power of Caeser, and the fear that he poses a threat to the republican liberty of Rome, a group of senators conspire to murder him. The ringleaders, Cassius (Richard Johnson), and Casca (Robert Vaughn), convince the moderate Brutus to carry out their plan on the steps of the Senate. Mark Antony’s famous and stirring funeral oration incites the Roman populus to bring the perpetrators to justice. Richard Chamberlain also co-stars as Octavius Caeser, who avenges Caeser’s death in a battle with Cassius and Brutus.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Commonwealth United, Republic Pictures Corporation, Peter Snell and Stuart Burge

results.title: Julius Caesar
results.creator_credit: RM Arts, English National Opera, Channel Four, John Copley and John Phillips
results.brief_description: Studio production recorded at Limehouse Studios, Docklands, London, of George Frideric Handel’s tale of love and power in three acts, “Julius Caesar”, with libretto by Nicola Haym in the edition by Noel Davies and Sir Charles Mackerras, English translation by Brian Trowell, performed by the English National Opera. Features Dame Janet Baker (Julius Caesar), Valerie Masterson (Cleopatra), Sarah Walker (Cornelia), Della Jones, (Sextus), James Bowman (Ptolemy) and John Tomlinson (Achillas) supported by the Orchestra and Chorus of the English National Opera conducted by Sir Charles Mackerras, Orchestra leader Russell Gilbert and Chorus master Victor Morris. This lavish production was specially made to coincide with Handel’s tercentenary in 1985. Booklet included.

results.title: Julius Caesar
results.brief_description: Film adaptation of Shakespeare’s “Julius Caesar” stars Charlton Heston in the role of Mark Antony and Harold Tasker as Julius Caesar. Cast includes Grosvenor Glenn, Robert Holt, Mary Sefton Darr. Video also contains a collector’s bonus in the form of a 10 minute minidoco on the making of “The Ten Commandments” presented by Cecil B. De Mille.

results.title: Juliette Ou la Clef des Songes = juliette or the key of dreams
results.brief_description:
Michel, a prisonner, escapes from his cell every night in dreams to be reunited with his beloved Juliette. In his pursuit of Juliette, Michel arrives in a god-forsaken village where all the inhabitants seem to have lost their memory. Continuity between Occupation and postwar cinema, though great, was far from absolute. At the level of film genre, the most notable change was the rapid decline of one of Occupation’s favored subjects: the fantastic. Stories of ghosts, prophetic dreams, devils and demons, love potions, and the like had greatly appealed to French filmmakers and audiences in the spiritual half-light of the occupied country. (…) The last major film of this trend, and of the period’s strong penchant for the fantastic, was Carne’s ‘Juliette ou la cle des songes’, a work which would certainly have a better reception had the director been able to make it when he first wanted to, in 1942. In 1951 it was a terrible anachronism, received with great hostility at the Cannes film festival and closing after a few weeks of mediocre box office returns, despite having Gerard Philipe (by then a big star) in the male lead.” Alan Williams. “Republic of images: a history of French filmmaking”. Harvard University Press, 1992. Awards: Cannes Film Festival 1951: Best music for Joseph Kosma.

Credits: Producer, Sacha Gordine ; director, Marcel Carne ; writer, Georges Neveux, Marcel Carne, Jacques Viot ; photography ; Henri Alekan ; music, Joseph Kosma ; art direction, Alexandre Trauner ; stills photographer, Raymond Voinquel.
Cast: Suzanne Cloutier, Gerard Philippe, Gabrielle Fontan, Jean-Roger Caussimon, Yves Robert.

results.title: Juliette et L'air du Temps = Juliet and the Feel of the Time
results.brief_description:
Eighteen-year old Juliette who grew up in a rural area in France has come to Paris to live. She scrapes by through begging, lives in a condemned building, and steals food occasionally at supermarkets. Her boyfriend would like her to settle down and get married, but Juliette seems to enjoy this hand-to-mouth existence.

Credits: Producer, Michel Chanderli ; director, Rene Gilson ; writer, Rene Gilson ; photography, Walter Baal ; music, Bernard Gilson.
Cast: Agnes Chateau, Jacques Zanetti, Mathieu Volta, Fabienne Arel, Janine Molinier.

results.title: Julien Donkey-boy
results.creator_credit: Independent Pictures, Scott Macaulay, Robin O'hara, Cary Woods and Harmony Korine
results.brief_description: The first American entry to Dogma 95 is the second feature for Harmony Korine who faithfully embraces the manifesto by improvising scenes, shooting digitally, only using available light and minimal post-sound. “Julien Donkey-boy” also utilizes the loose narrative (or non-narrative) structure of his controversial feature debut “Gummo” (1997), offering a series of randomly connected vignettes in the life of an ‘average’ American family. Ewen Bremner plays the title character, a child-like schizophrenic whom we first see as he murders a young boy, then promptly goes home and forgets about it. Korine serves up an uncomfortable portrait of family life for Julien: a dictatorial father who is prone to wearing a gas mask (played with glee by director Werner Herzog), his sister, Pearl (Chloe Sevigny), who is pregnant with Julien’s baby and a young wrestling obsessed brother (Evan Neumann) whose father pays him to dress up in his dead mother’s clothes. The films loose style and roving camera makes it feel uncomfortably documentary like at times, while the films grainy, ‘no-frills’ look produces some surprisingly haunting and beautiful images. Cast also includes Joyce Korine and Chrissy Kobylak.

results.title: Julie, your best just isn't good enough
results.brief_description: Julie left school early and as been in and out of jobs for four years. She has been unemployed for tem months and is willing to take any job. She talks about the dole, what she does with her money and about her parents.

results.title: Julie Stafford's taste of life : the video
results.creator_credit: Martin and Rosenthal Pictures, AAV Australia, Chris Weir and Malcolm Dwyer
results.brief_description: Best selling cookery writer Julie Stafford invites you to prepare a variety of mouth-watering recipes for breakfast, lunch, children’s meals and dinners for everyday and for special occasions. Julie also gives a brief outline of healthy foods to eat, shows how to choose and store them and gives an introduction to some common herbs. A weekly menu planner is included.

results.title: Julie Julie
results.brief_description: Julie was sick of living in Broken Hill, so she bought a motorbike and left to ride around Australia. The film shows part of her journey and illustrates the sense of freedom and independence of young people breaking loose.

results.title: Julia: critical moments in teaching (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Calvin Productions, United States. Dept. of Health, Education and Welfare, David Gliessman and Don G. Williams
results.brief_description: Julia, a naturally retiring child, becomes withdrawn in class. The school psychologist tests her and finds she has a hearing impairment. He recommends keeping Julia in her present class. Her teacher is suddenly confronted with the realisation that she has primary responsibility for Julia’s education. What steps should she take to help her?
